The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: The production values of this game are top notch. Graphics\, environments\, music and acting are great. One of the best of the current generation. Unfortunately the game is narrative driven and the writing is shoddy at best. The story is structured poorly\, the characters are shallow and act in incomprehensible fashion. My idea of a great game is to be put the player  in a world to make decisions and see how they play out. In this game I’m put into the world to do what the writers want\, without real agency.  For a big portion of the game I’m forced to act in a way I don’t want to\, and even worse\, play a character I don’t want to play with.The gameplay itself is very similar to the original\, almost no innovation\, and it feels both unfair and illogical at times. It is not fair that I’m against a dozen NPC:s with a gun\, but each time I can get only 1-2 billets from them. The scarcity is artificial and does not make sense. Playing with the Abby character\, a solider for several years\, is too similar to playing with Ellie. For some reason she learns about crafting\, gun improvements and close combat skills only on the days I’m playing the character\, the exact days when Ellie is in town. Unrelated to my rating\, I find Sony/Naughty Dog PR and marketing decisions suspicious. Not allowing the reviewers to talk about the whole game and misleading gamers on the content of the game was not cool\, almost like a bait-and-switch. Given the game they made\, I kinda understand\, but can not approve.… Expand
